text:
Is there such a thing as a "corporate" or "business" account within the Betfair setup? Been doing some low-level shitstirring on twitter and playing around with things in my mind and I was wondering how a syndicate operates, or indeed a bookmaking firm who wanted to reduce exposure by laying off on the exchange (I'm assuming this actualy does happen but correct me if that is wrong). It got me thinking about other things from recent discussions and of ways to "legitimise" what we do. For example, setting up a company/consultancy/whatever and passing off gambling profit as business profit - I know that would result in taxation of the profit which does seem like madness but would result in not being off the financial radar.
I've layed this out in quite a cumbersome manner, but hoping that people get the idea of what I am asking.

I've layed this out in quite a cumbersome manner, but hoping that people get the idea of what I am asking.

text: Yes, they accept corporate customers, see e.g. here: <https://support.betfair.com/app/answers/detail/a_id/91/~/what-is-the-corporate-identity-verification-process%3F>

elements.text: Yes, they accept corporate customers, see e.g. here:

text: Bet in your name, create a company, pay yourself a salary. Give director loans into the company forever

elements.text: Bet in your name, create a company, pay yourself a salary. Give director loans into the company forever

text: You can pay yourself to whatever optimises tax wise and be on the financial radar sufficient amount. Betting in personal name makes the most amount of sense

elements.text: You can pay yourself to whatever optimises tax wise and be on the financial radar sufficient amount. Betting in personal name makes the most amount of sense

text: Part of the motivation for my question is to look at ways to legitimately bet in other countries. I'm very concerned that the UK gambling industry is going to shit itself thanks to the interference from the UKGC. I regularly lose £1k + a day and without a job I will trigger one of these affordability checks. With no real employment, I will fail such a check and run the risk of having my account closed. I realise nothing is set in stone yet but I don't want to wait for it to happen before coming up with ideas to perpetuate my ability to keep on doing this.

elements.text: Part of the motivation for my question is to look at ways to legitimately bet in other countries. I realise nothing is set in stone yet but I don't want to wait for it to happen before coming up with ideas to perpetuate my ability to keep on doing this.

text: I think those checks only trigger if you deposit. Don't ever deposit (which means keep a good sized bank roll at exchange and be consistently profitable)

elements.text: I think those checks only trigger if you deposit. Don't ever deposit (which means keep a good sized bank roll at exchange and be consistently profitable)

text: Currently there is no legislation, but the white paper says they will be triggered on £1k+ in 24 hours or £2K+ over 90 days (don't quote me - going from memory). I keep a large bank because Ive heard that checks are triggered currently on "large" deposits (not deposited myself for a very long time) - but currently there is not a real requirement for an operator to do this. There will be if the white paper proposals become a legal requirement. There are vague notions of "net losses" but no timeframes taken into account. They explicitly state that lifetime profits will NOT be taken into account. I might get away with monthly net calculations, I'll be fine it its yearly net calculation but weekly, I could trigger. Its all very vague and uncertain and is why I want to start plannig ahead.

Its all very vague and uncertain and is why I want to start plannig ahead.

text:
It's an affordability check - if it arises you just have to prove you have the money - a regular job makes it easier but won't be mandatory so long as you can prove you have the capital. Can just see HRH having to do an affordability check at Epsom if he wants to bet a grand on a horse.
Personally I wouldn't go down the route of BF PC + Corporation Tax + PAYE + 'ers NI + tax on unearned income (dividends) when is non-taxable under current tax precedents other than BF PC.
As <@U01B8031PM1> said - don't deposit.

text: Have you read the white paper proposals? What you describe is pretty much exactly what UKGC want to happen and they want to get people to agree to open banking for this purpose. I'm sure most people will tell them where to shove it.

elements.text: Have you read the white paper proposals? What you describe is pretty much exactly what UKGC want to happen and they want to get people to agree to open banking for this purpose. I'm sure most people will tell them where to shove it.

text: No I haven't - I don't have a job and would never go near open banking so would have to prove the affordability if required.

elements.text: No I haven't - I don't have a job and would never go near open banking so would have to prove the affordability if required.

text: Me neither - but that's the tricky bit. If you've got a million+ in the bank you'll probably be OK. It appears they are looking for proof of INCOME more than anything. I'm hoping that it will get shot down soon but it is certainly a worry.

elements.text: Me neither - but that's the tricky bit. If you've got a million+ in the bank you'll probably be OK. It appears they are looking for proof of INCOME more than anything. I'm hoping that it will get shot down soon but it is certainly a worry.

text: If you are a professional gambler your income is derived from betting and the regularity and size of that can be demonstrated. Two issues will arise when you want to deposit a significant amount 1) where did the money come from (money laundering responsibilities)  2) (new) can you afford it without "harm". No deposit then no check to my way of thinking. BTW even if you green don't even think of calling yourself a "trader" as I often see suggested elsewhere - HMRC knows traders buy and sell things including intangibles and that people like that all pay tax.

text: I think maybe read the white paper - if it passes in the form it is in currently, then I see myself (any maybe others) having problems carrying on in this game. UKGC seem to want to base it all on losses rather than deposits but it that reverses we will all likely be fine. Fingers crossed anyway.
